results.title: Has beans
results.creator_credit: Andrew Tamandl, AFTRS and Miriam Stein
results.brief_description: The world is full of war and where can we hope to escape it? Home? - Certainly not by a stretch of this little computer animation. A lone kidney bean is being given the rough treatment by two much larger, bullying lima beans. In a number of fancy manoeuvres the kidney bean tricks the bullying two into believing they’ve killed him. When the kidney bean reaches his kin a battle of revenge is planned. The plan is foiled once ensconced in battle by the true ruler - he/she who cooks beans in the kitchen. The battle scenes are stylistically similar to and remniscent of the battle scenes in the paintings of Australian artist, John Bracks, where he used pencils and decks of cards symbolically and as structural elements to recreate battle scenes. No dialogue, sound effects only.

No dialogue, sound effects only.

results.title: Harry's War ( Crossing Tracks )
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, Jill Bilcock and John Foss
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Spotlights: Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama. Her films often feature female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors and also mentions My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in the New Wave section of Moving Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_primary.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

results.description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).

group.title: Spotlights

results.title: Melbourne (no. 1)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Brief shots of the Shrine of Rememberance.

Section 2. Shots of the 1848 building from several angles.

Section 3. A cricket match at the MCG. Sparse crowd. Several angles and shots, lasts for three minutes.

Section 4. Luna Park at night. Brief shot of the entrance and the exterior of a dogem cars attraction.

Section 5. Houses in Melbourne; older and ‘new’. Brief.

Section 6. Various shots of parks and gardens. Brief.

Section 7. Spencer Street rail yards, shot from above. Brief.

Section 8. A few shots of the city, including trams and St. Paul’s cathederal.

Section 9. Woman in a park, admiring a flower bed. Good close-ups.

Section 10. Camera pans up from the Yarra to St Paul’s Cathederal/city in the distance. Nice shot.

Section 11. Good shots of the city from the Yarra.

results.title: Princess of the Blood robes costume from The Last Emperor
results.brief_description: This costume from The Last Emperor enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.title_for_label: Princess of the Blood robes from The Last Emperor
results.description:
From seller: A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
description_for_label: Colour had arrived in cinema when The Last Emperor (1987) was released but its use in costume and cinematography was Oscar-winning. The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen and colour is fundamental to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates moments in jail later in life. This costume by James Acheson enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, further reinforced by 9,500 extras that appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.

results.title: S*it rentals with Melvin
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @PurplePinger's TikTok stream
results.brief_description: With his ironic analysis of rental property listings, @PurplesPingers has become a symbol of Australia’s frustration with the housing crisis. Using just a smartphone and a deadpan delivery, the activist and lawyer dissects the misleading and exaggerated claims of property listings, exposing the shoddy practices of real estate agencies and the dodgy conditions renters face. His videos have received over 4.3m likes on TikTok, leading him to be comment on the crises on news and morning shows. Though conservative hosts can be combative, the activist maintains his ironic detachment, employing logic and the law to dismantle their arguments.
results.description: With his ironic analysis of rental property listings, @PurplesPingers has become a symbol of Australia’s frustration with the housing crisis. Using just a smartphone, screenshots and deadpan delivery, the activist and lawyer dissects misleading and exaggerated property listings, exposing the shoddy practices of real estate agencies and the dodgy conditions renters face. With over 4.3m likes on TikTok, he’s been invited to comment on the crisis on traditional media. Though conservative hosts can be combative, the activist maintains his wry detachment, using logic and the law to undermine their arguments.
description_for_label: With his ironic analysis of rental property listings, @PurplesPingers has become a symbol of Australia’s frustration with the housing crisis. Using just a smartphone, screenshots and deadpan delivery, the activist and lawyer dissects misleading and exaggerated property listings, exposing the shoddy practices of real estate agencies and the dodgy conditions renters face. With over 4.3m likes on TikTok, he’s been invited to comment on the crisis on traditional media. Though conservative hosts can be combative, the activist maintains his wry detachment, using logic and the law to undermine their arguments.

results.title: Remixing Julia Gillard's misogyny speech
results.brief_description: This video remixes former Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s iconic ‘Misogyny Speech’ with an early example of the common ‘get ready with me’ TikTok trend. User Minorfauna readies to go out while lip-synching the famous speech, which Gillard delivered during a parliamentary address after being labelled sexist by the opposition leader. By mixing the speech with a trend largely perceived to be led by women, Minorfauna takes aim at sexist and outdated assumptions about women – much like Gillard, whose iconic speech was voted the most unforgettable moment in Australian TV history by Guardian readers.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

This video remixes former Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s iconic ‘Misogyny Speech’ with an early example of the common ‘get ready with me’ TikTok trend. User Minorfauna readies to go out while lip-synching the famous speech, which Gillard delivered during a parliamentary address after being labelled sexist by the opposition leader. By mixing the speech with a trend largely perceived to be led by women, Minorfauna takes aim at sexist and outdated assumptions about women – much like Gillard, whose iconic speech was voted the most unforgettable moment in Australian TV history by Guardian readers.
description_for_label: This video remixes former Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s iconic ‘Misogyny Speech’ with an early example of the common ‘get ready with me’ TikTok trend. User Minorfauna readies to go out while lip-synching Gillard’s famous parliamentary address, delivered after being labelled sexist by the opposition leader. By mixing the speech with a trend largely perceived to be led by women, Minorfauna takes aim at sexist and outdated assumptions about women, using the #bosschallenge hashtag to connect Gillard’s explosive comeback to women’s everyday experiences.
